conclusion: Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity with respect to time; represented by the slope of the velocity-time curve.
The velocity-time curve of Object B starts with a positive slope, decreases to a minimum (negative slope), and then increases again (positive slope).
Initially, the slope of the curve is positive and decreasing, indicating a decreasing positive acceleration.
At the turning point around \( t_1 \), the slope becomes negative, indicating negative acceleration (deceleration).
Beyond \( t_1 \), the slope starts to increase, indicating negative acceleration is decreasing (eventually approaching zero acceleration).
The red tangent lines illustrate the slope at different points on the curve: positive at the start, negative at \( t_1 \), less negative at \( t_2 \).
Initially, the acceleration is positive and decreasing.
Acceleration becomes zero at \( t_1 \) when the velocity is at a minimum.
From \( t_1 \) to \( t_2 \), the acceleration increases negatively, eventually approaching zero.
